III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation An unknown pregnant youth was not safe at the facility because
other youth were trying to assault her. Youth was moved to
another wing. About one week ago, an unknown youth was being
a danger to themselves and others around them. The pregnant
youth was in the same vicinity and put at risk of harm. Youth are
often exposed to dangerous behaviors of other youth. There is no
protocol for when a youth is aggressive.
Investigation Interviews:
Complaint Source was interviewed via phone on March 21,
2024. Complaint source noted she heard these safety concerns
for this pregnant youth from a staff but would not disclose the
staff’s name.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A was
identified as the pregnant youth within the allegations. She
reported she does not feel safe at the facility. When asked to
explain, Youth A reported there was a youth (later determined to
be Youth B) a couple of weeks ago that threatened her and
another youth (who was not able to be identified) about a month
ago threatened her. She stated she did not want to provide the
names of the youth. Youth A reported she feels better now that
she is no longer in the same unit as each of the youth, and she
2

does have supportive staff she can talk to. Youth A reported Youth
B had been talking negatively about her to another youth(that was
not identified). Youth A asked Youth B to stop talking about her
and Youth B told her no. Youth A and Youth B got into a verbal
argument. She reported she threw her yogurt at Youth B and
Youth B began to charge at her, but the staff went in between
them and separated them. Youth A reported she felt the staff did a
good job keeping her safe as they got her off the unit immediately.
She denied staff had restrained either of them and stated the staff
deescalated both youths.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B
reported she does not always get along with other youth on the
unit and noted one youth she did not get along with was Youth A.
Youth B reported one day Youth A thought Youth B was talking
about her so Youth A told her to stop talking about her. Youth B
told Youth A to mind her business and she was not talking about
her. The argument escalated and Youth A threw her yogurt at
Youth B. She reported this made her upset and Youth B got up to
go after Youth A. Youth B reported staff got in between both the
youth and separated them. She reported she was upset, went to
the bathroom, started crying, and that was how the argument
ended. Youth B reported Youth A was moved to a different unit
because they felt Youth A was not safe on the same unit as Youth
B. Youth B reported she agreed with the staff’s decision because
sometimes her anger explodes, and she will harm people. Youth B
reported when her anger explodes, staff do a good job of keeping
other youth away from her and letting her have her own space.
She reported staff will complete verbal check-ins with her and
continue to monitor her to make sure she is not a danger to
herself or others. Youth B reported staff have never gone into
physical restraint with her. Staff give her time to calm down and
talk her through the situation.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported
she was involved in the incident that occurred on March 15, 2024,
with Youth A and Youth B. She reported Youth B was talking to
another youth about someone and Youth A felt Youth B was
talking about her, so Youth A told Youth B to stop talking about
her. Youth B then told Youth A to “make me” and the verbal
argument escalated. Staff 1 reported Youth B stood up and Youth
A threw her yogurt at Youth B. At this point Youth B was starting
to charge after Youth A, so Staff 1 called for a clear, which alerted
other staff to come for support. She stated she got in between
3

Youth A and Youth B where her body was blocking Youth A for
her protection. Staff 1 reported she was able to get Youth A into a
separate area by coaching her and Youth B went with Staff 2. She
stated Youth A was moved to another unit for her safety. Staff 1
reported when youth are escalated, staff are to call a clear which
has other staff respond to support and remove the other youth off
the unit for safety. She reported staff are to use verbal de-
escalation and always maintain supervision of the youth. Staff 1
reported physical management only occurs if a youth is harming
themselves or physically harming someone else and this should
be used as a last resort. She reported all the youth have safety
plans, so staff are aware of how to best support the youth. Staff 1
reported these safety plans are in a binder in the staff office and
staff are to review them. She reported staff will also receive the
safety plans and any updates via email and in their weekly team
meetings.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported
she was involved in the incident on March 15, 2024, with Youth A
and Youth B. She reported Youth B was having a bad day and
was making comments about other youth despite being asked to
stop by staff. Staff 2 reported Youth B started talking about Youth
A to another youth and Youth A overheard it. She reported Youth
A and Youth B had a verbal argument over the situation. Staff 2
reported Youth A threw her yogurt at Youth B and Youth B started
to charge at Youth A. She reported she and Staff 1 got in between
the two youth so they would not physically fight one another. Staff
2 reported a clear was called and other staff had arrived to help.
Both of the youth were separated with the use of verbal de-
escalation, and she brought Youth B down to the restroom. Staff 2
reported there was no physical restraint that occurred, as staff
blocked the youth from harming one another and used verbal de-
escalation. She reported due to Youth A being pregnant she is
even more vulnerable, so they had to make sure to block Youth B
from attacking Youth A. Due to this situation, Youth A was moved
to another unit for her safety. Staff 2 reported staff are trained to
only use physical restraint model when the youth is a physical
danger to themselves or others and is used as a last resort. She
reported staff are trained to clear the room for safety, call for extra
support, use verbal de-escalation, allow youth to engage in a
voluntary time out, and use segregation for safety. She stated
when Youth B wanted to go to the bathroom that was the use of a
voluntary time out. Staff 2 reported when they use segregation,
that is when a staff gathers the other youth to bring them to
another area for safety. She reported all the youth have safety
4

plans as well which are in the staff office and staff emails. Staff 2
reported these are also reviewed weekly at the team meeting.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face via Microsoft Teams on
April 4, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3
reported her role at the facility is a team lead which means she
responds to more of the crises on the units. She reported she was
working on March 15, 2024, when Youth A and Youth B were in
an escalated situation. Staff 3 reported she walked in the unit after
the clear call and Youth A had already thrown the yogurt at Youth
B. She stated when she arrived on the unit, Staff 1 and Staff 2
were already in between Youth A and Youth B to avoid a physical
fight from occurring. Staff 3 reported she was the one to
encourage Youth B to walk away from the situation with Staff 2.
She reported the situation was handled appropriately by the staff.
Staff 3 reported she was the one to move Youth A’s items to
another unit for her safety. She reported staff are well equipped
with behavior management policies such as clearing the room and
use of verbal de-escalation. Staff 3 reported all youth to have an
initial risk assessment and ongoing safety plans that are provided
to all staff via email and stored in the staff office for review. She
stated the facility is constantly reviewing behavior management
techniques and talking about the youth’s safety plans in the
weekly team meeting. Staff 3 reported staff are to only use
physical restraints when a youth is a danger to themselves or
others.
Staff 4 and Staff 5 were interviewed separately via phone on
April 17, 2024. Staff 4 and Staff 5 reported when they arrived to
provide support for the incident on March 15, 2024, Youth A and
Youth B had already been separated from one another. Staff 4
reported when she arrived, Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 were
already positioned in between Youth A and Youth B. She reported
she assisted with unlocking the door to have Youth A exit off the
unit with Staff 1. Staff 5 reported when she arrived, Youth A was
already exiting the unit and assisted with verbally de-escalating
Youth B. Staff 4 and Staff 5 reported the incident was handled
appropriately.
Video Footage reviewed:
Video footage of the incident that occurred on March 15, 2024,
was reviewed by this consultant on April 1, 2024. The footage
begins at 08:04am with Staff 1 and Staff 2 sitting monitoring the
six youth on the unit. Youth A is sitting with some other youth and
Youth B is sitting in her own area closer to where Staff 1 and Staff
2 are sitting. Youth B begins to talk to another youth on the unit. At
5

8:05am, Youth A and Youth B begin to talk to one another. Staff 1
and Staff 2 go to the milieu area where Youth A and Youth B are.
Within 30 seconds, Youth A stands ups and throws yogurt at
Youth B. During that time, Staff 1 is standing in between the two
youth. Youth B get ups off her chair and rushes at Youth A. Staff 3
enters the unit and stands up between Youth A and Youth B with
Staff 1 and Staff 2. Both the youth attempt to attack one another
while staff block the youth from one another. Staff 1 gets Youth A
away from Youth B and brings her into the side room. Staff 2
walks with Youth B down to the bathroom area. This incident was
about two minutes in total long. Staff 3, Staff 4 and Staff 5 came
onto the unit to assist with support.
Documentation Reviewed:
- Facility Incident Report dated March 15, 2024- Youth A
got upset with Youth B due to Youth B talking about Youth
A to another youth. Youth A had questioned Youth B about
this which caused Youth B to become verbally aggressive.
Youth A threw her yogurt towards Youth B. Staff 1 stood in
the middle of both youth to try to diffuse the situation. Youth
B attempted to reach over Staff 2 to hit Youth A. Staff 1 and
Staff 2 continued to use verbal redirection to de-escalate
the situation. Staff 2 was able to verbally redirect Youth A
and walked her down to her room to help calm down. Staff
3 came onto the unit and assisted with verbal de-escalation
with Youth B and was able to get her to calm down. Youth
A was moved to another wing of the building for safety.
- Youth A’s File- Youth A has had only one incident report
since being at the facility. This incident report is listed
above.
- Youth A’s Youth Behavior Management Risk
Assessment dated August 23, 2024- This assessment
alerts staff that Youth A has a history of AWOL, Truancy,
Substance Abuse, Neglect and Sexual abuse. The
assessment also alerts staff that Youth A is pregnant.
Youth A reported her triggers are when people go back and
forth at one another. Some effective intervention
techniques for staff to use are writing, singing, dancing,
going for a walk and using fidget toys. This assessment
was signed by the youth, program supervisor and intake
worker.
- Youth A’s Safety Plan dated March 18, 2024- There was
no previous safety plan for Youth A prior to this incident.
The safety plan was created due to the incident that
6

occurred on March 15, 2024. This safety plan was
addressed for all staff who work with Youth A completed by
Therapist. The plan states the Youth A will be on 10-foot
space from other youth, will not buddy up with certain youth
in the program, Youth A cannot sit next to specific youth at
the facility, all interactions with specific youth should always
be monitored to ensure there is no verbal or physical
alterations, and this plan will continue to be monitored
weekly at team meetings.
- Youth B’s Youth Behavior Management Risk
Assessment dated May 11, 2023- This assessment alerts
staff that Youth B has history of self-harm. The assessment
also notes the youth gets triggers by people talking about
death and other youth “irritating her”. Some effective
intervention techniques for staff to use are positive
reinforcements, time alone, walking, listening to music, and
being talked to in a calm/low voice. This assessment was
signed by the youth, program supervisor and intake worker.
- Youth B’s File- Youth B has had numerous safety plans
since being placed at the facility. Prior to the incident that
occurred on March 15, 2024, Youth B had a safety plan
from January 25, 2024, due to self-harm. This safety plan
noted Youth B should remain in eyesight of staff and staff
should keep all sharps away from Youth B. It was
recommended staff do check ins with Youth B throughout
the shift, especially if Youth B is isolating herself away from
other peers.
- Youth B’s Safety Plan dated March 18, 2024- This safety
plan was addressed for all staff who work with Youth B
completed by Therapist. The safety plan was created in
response to the incident that occurred on March 15, 2024.
The plan states the Youth B will be on 10-foot space from
other youth, will not buddy up with certain youth in the
program, Youth B cannot sit next to specific youth at the
facility, all interactions with specific youth should always be
monitored to ensure there is no verbal or physical
alterations, and this plan will continue to be monitored
weekly at team meetings.
- Staff 1’s Training Records- Staff 1 is up to date with all
required trainings. Staff 1 completed the restraint model,
CPI, refresher training on November 16, 2023. She also
completed Policy and Procedure Review on May 24, 2023.
The policy and procedures are reviewed at team meetings
7

depending on the need within the unit but once a year they
do documentation of the review of all policy and
procedures.
- Staff 2’s Training Records- Staff 2 is newer staff to the
facility and has recently completed her onboarding. She is
in compliance with all required training. Staff 2 completed
the restraint model, CPI, full two-day training on February
5, 2024, and February 6, 2024. She completed Employee
Training Guide, which reviews all the policies and
procedures on February 8, 2024. Staff 2 also completed the
onboarding training “How Would You Handle This?” on
January 31, 2024 to learn more what to do in crisis
situations.
- Staff 3’s Training Records- Staff 3 is up to date with all
required trainings. Staff 3 completed the restraint model,
CPI, training refresher on March 14, 2023. It should be
noted she did complete the refresher for this year but has
not updated on the training list as it was done after this
report was pulled. The updated training was confirmed to
have been done the week on March 11, 2024. She also
completed Policy and Procedure Review on May 24, 2023.
The policy and procedures are reviewed at team meetings
depending on the need within the unit but once a year they
do documentation of the review of all policy and
procedures.
- Staff 4’s Training Records- Staff 4 is up to date with all
required trainings. Staff 4 completed the restraint model,
CPI, on September 7, 2023 and September 8, 2023. Staff 4
is a newer staff that started in August 2023 and completed
all onboarding requirements by the start of September 2023
which was a review of all required policies and procedures.
- Staff 5’s Training Records- Staff 5 is up to date with all
required trainings. Staff 5 completed the restraint model,
CPI, refresher training on November 16, 2023. She also
completed Policy and Procedure Review on May 24, 2023.
- Vista Maria Behavior Management Policy recently
reviewed on August 2022- This policy noted staff are to
use non-physical intervention skills, such as verbal de-
escalation, medication conflict resolution, active listening,
and verbal and observational methods to prevent
emergency safety situations. Staff are also trained on Crisis
Prevention Institute (CPI) training which is ongoing training
annually. This policy notes all youth will have a Youth
8

Behavior Management Risk Assessment/Safety Plan
completed by the Intake Department Staff upon admission
which is also provided to staff to help support the youth.
Staff are also trained on De-escalation, Voluntary Time Out
(VTO), Segregation for Safety, Therapeutic De-escalation,
Escort and Physical Intervention (CPI) to help support the
youth’s behaviors. Voluntary Time Out is noted when a
youth voluntary requests removal from a stressful situation
in order to utilize their coping strategies. Segregation For
Safety is when one youth is having increased behaviors
and staff is in charge of getting the other youth out of the
area so they are not exposed to the behaviors.
- Vista Maria Work Instructions- Behavior Management
approved on June 2012-This is workflow for staff and
supervisors to use when behavior management
interventions are used for a youth posing a danger to
themselves or others. This is a step-by-step guide to help
staff know when to clear an area, when to use verbal de-
escalation, call for support, what to do if a restraint is used
and what documentation needs to be completed.
- Vista Maria Client Supervision Policy approved date
March 2021- This policy notes how youth on all units are to
be continually supervised. It notes the shift supervisor is
responsible for supervising youth and floor staff on the unit
and must be able to account for them. One staff (this may
be the supervisor or team lead) must be free to carry out
the following tasks: periodically walk around the building,
complete a security check, account for all clients, and
assist in a crisis or in moving clients, if needed. The
reflects, “the supervisor must ensure that both clients and
staff are adequately protected in the event of an emergency
or disturbance.”
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with the rule. From watching
video footage and interviews, the staff at the facility responded
quickly to the situation and separated the youth for safety. Within
interviews, staff were knowledgeable about the facilities policies
and safety plans of the youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Emergency restraint
Title
9

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160
Section (1) The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others from
an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places the
youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are trained to restrain youth when they start destroying
property. Windows and walls have been boarded up for the past
week from a child being destructive and destroying property.
Investigation Interviews:
Complaint Source was interviewed via phone on March 21,
2024. Complaint source noted she heard these concerns from a
staff at the facility but would not disclose the staff’s name.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A was
asked about what staff do when youth are acting out or being
destructive. She reported staff will call a clear to keep the other
youth safe on the unit and will only restrain the youth if they are
dangerous to themselves or others. Youth A reported when a
clear is called, the youth will go with a staff into another area of
the building or into their rooms to get away from the youth acting
out. She denied staff would just restrain a youth due to doing
property damage. Youth A reported staff tried to talk a youth down
or give them their space.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B
reported staff only restrain a youth when they are harming
themselves or others. She reported she has completed property
damage on the unit and has never been restrained. Youth B
reported staff will clear the area of the other youth and try to
remove any physical objects they can from the youth. She
reported she has destroyed items in her room before and staff will
monitor her actions. Youth B stated that they would give her space
but also try to use verbal de-escalation with her. She denied staff
would just restrain a youth for property damage. Youth B reported
a youth needs to be harming themselves or attacking others to be
restrained.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 was
asked how staff are trained to respond when a youth is destroying
10

property. She reported staff are trained to clear the room so that
the other youth get out of the area where this is occurring. Staff 1
reported staff will then remove objects from the area, especially
any potentially dangerous items. She reported the staff maintain
supervision and lets the youth calm down on their own. Staff 1
reported staff let the youth “rant” and try to verbally de-escalate if
appropriate. She reported if the youth begins to harm themselves
or physically harm others then CPI restraint model can be used as
the last resort. Staff 1 reported staff would not restrain a youth for
property damage.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported
if a youth is acting out, throwing things, and/or destroying
property, staff are to try to verbally talk with the youth and call a
clear, so the other youth are out of potential danger. Staff 2
reported staff are to let the youth calm down and continue to use
verbal de-escalation skills they are taught. She reported staff are
not allowed to restrain a youth just because of property damage.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face via Microsoft Teams on
April 4, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3
reported the only time a youth would be put into physical restraint
by staff is when they are a danger to themselves or others. She
reported if a youth is damaging property staff are to clear the area,
continue to verbally de-escalate the youth, and monitor their
behavior. Staff 3 reported if a youth starts to punch out windows
causing harm to their hands, then there is a potential restraint
might occur.
Documentation Reviewed:
- Vista Mara Behavior Management Policy recently
reviewed in August 2022- This policy notes the facility
strictly prohibits excessive or inappropriate use of behavior
management intervention. Behavior management
interventions will not be used as a form of discipline or to
force compliance, for convenience of staff, or for property
damage that does not involve threatening danger to self or
others. Hands-on physical management techniques may be
utilized if the youth required an involuntary escort, is in
danger to harm to self or others and all other de-escalation
techniques have failed to resolve the imminent crisis
situation.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance of the rule. Within interviews,
staff and youth confirmed the staff do not restraint a youth unless
11

they are a danger to themselves or others. Staff noted within
interviews if a youth is causing property damage, they try to
verbally redirect the situation and clear the area of other youth and
dangerous items.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are no mental health protocols or procedures for staff on
how to handle suicide attempts, self-harming, violence against
other youth and staff other than restraints.
Investigation Interviews:
Complaint Source was interviewed via phone on March 21,
2024. Complaint Source reported at the facility there has been a
lot of high-risk youth with suicidal concerns and the facility does
not have protocols to help these youth.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A
reported she is assigned a therapist at the facility, but she does
not like talking to her because she does not know her. Youth A
reported staff take it very seriously if a youth threatens to harm
themselves. She reported the youth will immediately go on 100%
status and have their room cleared out of any potential items that
they could harm themselves with. Youth A denied ever being on
100% status.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B
reported that if a youth is talking about suicide or self-harming,
staff will remove all items from the youth’s room that they could
harm themselves with. She reported the youth will be placed onto
100% status where they will need to be always watched by staff.
Youth B reported one day she was having a bad day and was
shutting down in her room. She reported staff unsecured her door
and sat in the doorway to perform check-ins with her. Youth B
reported it was helpful. She reported she also sees her therapist
12

at the facility often and they will continue to perform checks and
note in her safety plan how staff can support her.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported
they are very well trained on what to do to support a youth if they
make any suicidal statement or self-harm. She reported staff are
to always take the comments seriously and call a team lead or
supervisor immediately for support. All potential risk items will be
removed from the youth’s room and the youth will be placed on
heightened supervision. The therapist will be notified of the
situation immediately. Staff 1 reported all the youth have ongoing
safety plans that are reviewed every week at the team meeting
with the therapist so that staff know how to best support the youth
if they are suicidal, self-harm, or have behavioral concerns. She
reported staff are trained to use the restorative tasks to help make
the youth successful within the program. Staff 1 reported the staff
are trained on all the policies related to these techniques monthly
so that it is at the forefront of the staff's minds. She stated staff
have access to all policies created by the facility through their
computer system or posted in the staff office. Staff 1 reported
when in doubt she could always call for support from another staff,
team lead, or supervisor. She reported restraint model is only
used in emergencies where a youth is a danger to themselves or
others.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported
staff are trained monthly on the protocols that are related to
suicide, self-harm, and behavior management. She reported if a
youth makes any suicidal comment or self-harms, the team lead
or supervisor needs to be called immediately. The youth will have
their room cleared of any potential risk items and get put on higher
supervision status. Staff 2 reported she has not encountered this
situation yet but is aware she will need to call for immediate
assistance if she does. Staff 2 reported staff are also provided
with all the youth’s safety plans via email and review them at
every team meeting. This is helpful so staff are aware of how to
best support and monitor the youth. Staff 2 reported staff are
trained to only use the physical restraint model when the youth is
a physical danger to themselves or others and is used as a last
resort.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face via Microsoft Teams on
April 4, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3
reported there are numerous policies put into place for staff on
13

how to handle a youth’s behaviors, if a youth is suicidal, and if a
youth self-harms. She reported staff are constantly being trained
on these policies and there is a policy binder located on the unit.
Staff 3 reported when staff are unsure what to do, they should be
calling a team lead or supervisor immediately for additional
support. She reported she has no concerns with the staff she
works with ability to address these concerns on the unit
appropriately.
Documentation Reviewed:
- Vista Maria Work Instruction Critical Incidents
approved date September 2016- This work instruction
was created to instruct staff to recognize potential critical
incidents and dangerous behaviors and take appropriate
steps to prevent them. Critical incidents include if a youth is
showing signs of suicidal behavior or threats are made to
harm another youth. Staff are to contact shift supervisor
immediately and follow documentation protocol.
- Vista Maria Client Supervision Policy approved date
March 2021- This policy notes how youth on all units are to
be continually supervised. It is noted the shift lead or
supervisor remains out of ratio to do periodical walks
around the building and be available to assist in crisis
situations.
- Vista Maria Behavior Management Policy recently
reviewed in August 2022- This policy noted staff are to
use non-physical intervention skills, such as verbal de-
escalation, medication conflict resolution, active listening,
and verbal and observational methods to prevent
emergency safety situations. This policy notes all youth will
have a Youth Behavior Management Risk Assessment
completed by the Intake Department Staff upon admission
which is also provided to staff to help support the youth.
Staff are also trained on De-escalation, Voluntary Time Out
(VTO), Segregation for Safety, Therapeutic De-escalation,
Crisis and Physical Intervention (CPI) to help support the
youth’s behaviors.
- Vista Maria Work Instructions- Behavior Management
approved in June 2012-This is workflow for staff and
supervisors to use when behavior management
interventions are used for a client posing a danger to
themselves or others. This is a step-by-step guide to help
guide staff of when to clear an area, when to use verbal de-
14

escalation, call for support, what to do if a restraint is used
and what documentation needs to be completed.
- Vista Maria Suicide Prevention Policy approved on
April 2016- This policy states that in event of a suicide
threat and/or attempt, the shift supervisor must seek
immediate medical attention for the client, if necessary. If
the client does not need medical attention but cannot be
controlled, then the client must be placed on confinement
status. The youth can be placed on observation status
which they will have a status of either 100% observation or
15-minute interval checks which is determined by the
therapist/psychiatrist or building manager. Staff are to notify
the building manager or on-call program manager who will
notify the therapy and psychiatrist of this situation to assist
with next steps.
- Vista Maria Work Instructions Suicide Prevention
approved in April 2016- This is a step-by-step guide for
shift supervisor, staff, therapist and leadership to properly
address any threat of suicide seriously and steps to prevent
suicide among the youth. This lays out the different levels
of what the youth can be on and what steps need to be
taken and by who to keep the youth safe.
- Vista Maria Client Observation Policy approved in
March 2016- This policy is for staff to ensure safety of all
the youth and see what certain behavior may indicate the
need for client observation level. Examples that were
provide in this policy if the youth’s behavior includes talk of
suicide, talk of hurting themselves or others, or talk of
truancy. The policy explains the different levels of
observations and who makes the decision for the level and
duration.
- Vista Maria High Risk Clients Policy revised date
February 2009- This policy notes the facility will accept
youth that have high risk behaviors which included
pregnancy, history of fire stetting or prefatory behavior. The
goal is for the facility to serve these youth and prevent
psychological and physical victimization of other residents.
The high-risk clients will be served through having special
treatment plans and using restrictive behavior management
techniques as a last resort in a crisis situation.
- Vista Maria Restorative Tasks Policy approved date
August 2020- This policy states that staff will use the
restorative approach to help build a therapeutic alliance
15

and encourages healthy interactions with the youth. This
approach is used for responding when youth hurt
themselves or others and to help operationalize trauma-
informed care in group settings. This policy goes through
what restorative task approach is and how staff is to utilize
it with youth.
- Vista Maria Work Instruction Restorative Tasks
approved date November 2018- This work guide
describes procedures for creating and implanting effective
restorative tasks for the staff to use with the youth.
- Training records of Staff 1, Staff 2 and Staff 3- Staff 1,
Staff 2, and Staff 3’s training records were reviewed to
review what trainings are occurring at the facility and how
staff are getting an understanding of these policies and
procedures. Within the year of 2023 to present staff have
completed trainings that included CPI Training both the full
training and annual refreshers, Policy and Procedure
Review, Employee Behavior Policy Review, Safety
Planning for the youth at the facility, Six Core Strategies,
and PREA- Annual Refresher.
- Staff 2’s Emails- During the face-to-face interview with
Staff 2 on March 29, 2024, Staff 2 showed this consultant
her emails that have been sent out weekly with updates of
the youth safety plans and reviews of policy and
procedures. The review of the emails appeared to be follow
up emails from the weekly staff meetings that was spoken
about throughout interviews.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance of having appropriate policies
and procedures in place to handle behaviors, self-harm, and
suicidal ideation. Within documentation review there was found to
be numerous policies and workflows that staff were knowledge of
within interviews. Training records were also reviewed that
showed staff are properly trained within these policies and
procedures.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Type
Allegation Staff and youth are unsafe because of a lack of staff on shift.

Investigation Interviews:
Complaint Source was interviewed via phone on March 21,
2024. Complaint source noted she heard these concerns from a
staff at the facility but would not disclose the staff’s name.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A
reported there is typically two or three staff working on a unit at
the time. She stated there has to be one staff to every three youth
and she had no concerns with them not following that model.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B
reported there always needs to be one staff for every three youth
unless there is a youth that needs increased staffing. She reported
there are always two to four staff working on the unit with about
six or seven youth. Youth B reported she felt there was enough
staff to control the unit.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported
the ratio at the facility is one staff for every three youths. She
stated sometimes there are youth on one-to-one status, but a
certain staff will be assigned to that youth. Staff 1 reported she
has never been understaffed on a shift and does not have
concerns about the ratio. She reported if there is a potential for a
shift to be short-staffed then management works on finding a fill-
in, using the designated stay-over staff, or management
themselves will work the shift.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
29, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported
she works multiple different shifts at the facility. She stated the
ratio is one staff to every three youth, unless there is a heightened
one to one then there is a specific staff assigned to that youth.
Staff 2 reported she has never been out of ratio at the facility. She
reported if there is a potential for a shift to be short-staffed then
management works on finding a fill-in, using the designated stay-
over staff, or management themselves will work the shift. Staff 2
17

reported she has no concerns with the facility not being in
compliance with their ratio and stated she has not heard concerns
from others about that either.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face via Microsoft Teams on
April 4, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3
reported she has no concerns with the ratio at the facility. She
reported they always operate with more staff than the ratio
required. Staff 3 reported some youth do need a higher level of
staffing so having that extra support is needed. She reported she
feels that the facility is sufficiently staffed.
